org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.tests.lang

Class UpdatableResultSetTest

  • java.lang.Object
    • junit.framework.Assert
      • junit.framework.TestCase
        • org.apache.derbyTesting.junit.BaseTestCase
          • org.apache.derbyTesting.junit.BaseJDBCTestCase
            • org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.tests.lang.UpdatableResultSetTest
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    junit.framework.Test

    public class UpdatableResultSetTest
extends BaseJDBCTestCase
    This tests JDBC 2.0 updateable resultset - deleteRow, updateRow, and insertRow API

      Positive test - use prepared statement with concur updatable status to test deleteRow
      void testDeleteRowWithSetCursorName()
      Positive test - change the name of the statement when the resultset is open and see if deleteRow still works This test works in embedded mode since Derby can handle the change in the name of the statement with an open resultset But it fails under Network Server mode because JCC and Derby Net Client do not allow statement name change when there an open resultset against it

      Positive test - Another test case for delete trigger

      void testRowDeleted()
      Positive test - For Forward Only resultsets, DatabaseMetaData will return false for ownDeletesAreVisible and deletesAreDetected This is because, after deleteRow, we position the ResultSet before the next row.

      void testUpdateRowWithSetCursorName()
      Positive test - change the name of the statement when the resultset is open and see if updateRow still works This test works in embedded mode since Derby can handle the change in the name of the statement with an open resultset But it fails under Network Server mode because JCC and Derby Net Client do not allow statement name change when there an open resultset against it

      • testRowDeleted

        public void testRowDeleted()
                    throws java.sql.SQLException
        Positive test - For Forward Only resultsets, DatabaseMetaData will return false for ownDeletesAreVisible and deletesAreDetected This is because, after deleteRow, we position the ResultSet before the next row. We don't make a hole for the deleted row and then stay on that deleted hole
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException

      • testDeleteRowWithSetCursorName

        public void testDeleteRowWithSetCursorName()
                                    throws java.sql.SQLException
        Positive test - change the name of the statement when the resultset is open and see if deleteRow still works This test works in embedded mode since Derby can handle the change in the name of the statement with an open resultset But it fails under Network Server mode because JCC and Derby Net Client do not allow statement name change when there an open resultset against it
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException
